ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A guided introduction to the main topics in commutative algebra and category theory. (Start refreshing rings, ideals, specialized types of rings, constructions in linear algebra such as direct sum, etc.)

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think it would be helpful to have chapters of textbooks linked to lectures. This would allow for outside reading to get slightly different perspectives of the same material.

Strong lecture notes and references are much appreciated. It is important to reread solutions and weigh the various methods for proving a statement. Most of all, you should try to ask about the "why" behind seemingly obvious and mundane statements. There is always a chance that these obvious statements are in fact more subtle than you think: you are expected to rise to the challenge of a certain level of rigor.
Course was very well-organized and Prof. Losev was always accessible

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, the professor is excellent and the delivery of the material was clear.

This is a class where you can grow substantially as a mathematician. The skills you learn are much more than just algebra: they are an impetus to begin becoming aware of the subtleties of mathematical motivation, definition, and substance.
